thread.title: National Vet Care no dog in first day of trading

title: National Vet Care no dog in first day of trading
text:

Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Puppy Jo unperturbed by ASX Golden labrador puppies, Flo and Jo, help ring the bell for the Australian stock exchange on Friday to launch the listing for National Veterinary Care.
PT1M3S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Newly listed company National Veterinary Care aims to have finalised the acquisition of 35 clinics by next week, after a solid debut on the ASX on Friday.
The Brisbane-based company soared 21 per cent to close at $1.21 a share in its first day of trading, giving the group a market value of $60 million.
Chief executive Tom Steenackers and NVC chairwoman Susan Forrester posed for photos with Labrador puppies on the floor of the Australian Securities Exchange in Sydney to mark the listing.
National Vet Care chairwoman Susan Forrester with a Labrador puppy on the floor of the Australian Securities Exchange in Sydney to mark the listing.
"My feeling is excitement. Now we can really start putting the strategy in place. We move from 15 employees last week to 400," Mr Steenackers said.
Advertisement The float, which raised almost $30 million, was oversubscribed three times as investors backed the company to emulate the success of bigger rival Greencross.
Greencross listed in 2007 with a market value of about $30 million and is worth $800 million now.
Greencross disappointed the market with an earnings downgrade earlier in 2015 but after a solid full-year result this week the stock bounced 14 per cent in a day.
"Greencross and NVC have a different model," Mr Steenackers, a former general manager of Greencross, said.
"We are focusing on professional services and a big portion of revenue for them is retail. I think there is space for both players."
The $30 million raised in the IPO will fund the acquisition of NVC's first 35 clinics. NVC has already settled 30 of those transactions and expects to close the remaining five by Wednesday next week.
Mr Steenackers said he was focused on integrating the businesses just acquired and driving organic growth through increasing the skills of staff.
A core plank of NVC's strategy is to offer regular training opportunities for its vets and nurses in areas like pathology, surgery, and dental.
This should allow difficult procedures to stay in-house rather than being referred to non-NVC specialists and will allow nurses to take on bigger roles, freeing up the vets to do more complex tasks.
Mr Steenackers said NVC aimed to acquire one new clinic every two months in its first year and might increase that rate in 2016.
Following the listing NVC is the second-biggest player in the Australian vet sector.
More than 60 per cent of the nation's households own a pet. The veterinary services industry in Australia is estimated to be worth $2.6 billion a year, while the pet industry is worth about $8 billion a year.
The float was underwritten by Shaw Stockbroking and Wilston HTM.
